subject: AUDIO SERVICE HAS NOW CLOSED FOR THE WEEK. THE ASIA DESK WILL REOPEN ON SUNDAY AT 2200GMT, EUROPEAN SERVICE WILL RESUME ON MONDAY AT 0630GMT. HAVE A PLEASANT WEEKEND.
US MARKET WRAP: Trump signs omnibus bill amid on-going Trade Wars
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equities down, USD lower, Treasuries up, crude higher.

* REAR-VIEW: Trade Wars continue to feed risk-off; Solid CAD CPI; Fed's Bostic turns centrist; BOE's Vliege tilting hawkish.

* NEXT-WEEK: Fed's Rosengren (Fri); US PCE, US GDP, Trade Wars, lots of Fedspeak.

* EQUITIES: SPX -2.08% at 2589, NDX -2.61% at 6508, DJI -1.77% at 23535

* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): -1.64%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -1.14%, ENERGY (XLE): -0.59%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -2.62%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -1.97%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -1.20%, MATERIALS (XLB): -1.77%, TECH (XLK): -2.17%, TELECOMS (XTL): -1.65%, UTLITIES (XLU): -1.47%.

* US equity futures experienced choppy trade today due to ongoing Trade War concerns, with China mulling $3bln worth of tariffs on numerous US products, such as steel, pipes, wine and pork which hampered stocks in early trade. Threats by US President Trump that he would potentially veto the government funding bill also kept equities on the back foot, though rallied after he signed the bill, that will keep the government open until September, though the rally proved fragile, and selling action returned as traders settled up for the week, pushing shares to session lows. During the choppy trade, the VIX rose to above 25 again, the highest since 2 March. Also, in late trade SPX broke the psychological level 2600 and headed towards the 200d ma, 2590, which it bounced off on the close. Looking to stock-specifics, S&P was being led by Foot Locker (FL) following positive earnings from Nike (NKE) after market on Thursday; Cintas was positive on earnings; and defence names (LMT, NOC, RTN) up following an increased budget for the US military.

* FOREX: DXY closes the week -0.8% Havens (JPY, EUR, CHF) all higher on the day, as the DXY ends Friday 0.5% lower (down around 0.8% for the week, snapping two weeks of gains). Despite the roller-coaster rides seen this week, the DXY range between 89.40 and 90.50 has held. Gold is up, buoyed by a weak dollar and lower yields. CAD is one of the top performers on Friday, following solid CPI data (which offset mediocre retail data) which saw the average of the three BOC measures (trimmed mean, median, and common) jumped to 2.03% (versus 1.83% in the January data) above the BOC's 2% midpoint of its 1-3% target range. The data did little to push a repricing for the April BOC meeting, though the July and October meetings are now fully priced. GBP is higher against the USD, helped by hawkish comments from BOE's Vlieghe (data has moved in a direction that warrants removal of stimulus), though couldn't carve out gains vs the EUR. EMFX is up against the USD, with the exception of TRY. Other commodity FX (AUD, NZD) trades higher, following Trade War speculation that China may sway towards Australian imports rather than US imports.

* TREASURIES: US T-Note futures (Jun'18) settle 3 ticks higher at 120-19+. The Tsy curve bulls-steepened, catching a bid amid soft risk-appetite on the back of Trade Wars fears. Yields on 2s lower by around 3bps, as were 5s, while 10s yields were 1bps lower, and 30s were unchanged in thin volume. Some analysts have expressed astonishment that 10-year yields haven't managed to meaningfully breach the 2.80% level to the downside (while the 3.00% level seems to be solidly reinforced), in spite of soft risk sentiment. One desk noted that it may be a function of shorts sitting on tidy profits this year, giving them a thicker buffer to absorb losses due to rallies. Other desks have suggested that levels near/sub 2.80% have represented good areas to add shorts. 

* CRUDE: WTI futures settle $1.53 at $65.71 (Jun'18); Brent settles $1.42 higher at $68.38 (Jun'18). Front month backwardation (M8/N8 spread) widened by 7 cents to 42 cents on the day. The geopolitical risk premium in crude has driven sharp gains in WTI this week, and WTI finishes green for the third straight week. Markets have taken the nominations of Mike Pompeo (as Sec of State) and John Bolton (as Nat Sec advisor) as a hawkish sign that the US is tilting towards backing out of the Iran nuclear deal in May, and reapplying sanctions on the country – which would likely hinder Iran in raising capital to finance a boost to refinery output. Along with a healthy dose of optimistic jawboning from OPEC Sec Gen Barkindo earlier in the week, (the worst is over for the oil market) and Saudi energy minister Al Falih yesterday, (who sees cooperation between OPEC+ in 2019) helping to support crude prices amid distinctly risk-off tone this week, where equities slid.

subject: WTI crude futures settle higher by USD 1.53 at USD 69.81 (June 2018); Brent Crude futures settle USD 1.42 higher at USD 68.38 (June contract)
content: • Front month backwardation (M8/N8 spread) widened by 7 cents to 42 cents on the day.
analysis_details: • The geopolitical risk premium in crude has driven sharp gains in WTI this week, for the third straight week. Markets have taken the nominations of Mike Pompeo (as Sec of State) and John Bolton (as Nat Sec advisor) as a hawkish sign that the US is tilting towards backing out of the Iran nuclear deal in May, and reapplying sanctions on the country – which would likely hinder Iran in raising capital to finance a boost to refinery output. Along with a healthy dose of optimistic jawboning from OPEC Sec Gen Barkindo (the worst is over for the oil market) and Saudi energy minister Al Falih (who sees cooperation between OPEC+ in 2019) helping to support crude prices amid distinctly risk-off tone this week, where equities slid.

Weekly FX wrap: JPY trading at best levels since Nov’16 on trade wars, GBP among top G10 performers after Brexit breakthrough
content:
USD, JPY : This week saw trade wars escalate after President Trump announced tariffs OF USD 50bln against China over intellectual property theft. In retaliation to this, China announced tariffs on USD 3bln of US imports. Subsequently, risk sentiment had been dented, notably benefiting the JPY across the board, which saw USD/JPY reached the lowest level since Nov’16 after tripping through YTDs low of 105.23. Aside from protectionist policies, Wednesday saw the FOMC hike rates, the greenback ultimately softened after members maintained 2018 rate path view of 3 rate hikes (1 member away from median projection at 4). Additionally, the central bank steepened the path of rate hikes for 2019-2020, however the council did soften language around activity. DXY back down to mid-89 while March lows of 89.40 continue to act as support.

GBP: Brexit breakthrough after the UK and EU agree transition with an Irish border back-stop, providing good news for the GBP bulls, which saw the currency among the top G10 currencies for the week. Elsewhere, the Bank of England’s hawkish vote split took the spot rate past 1.42, however, the central bank refrained from confirming a rate hike is a done deal for May (current pricing at 60%), with much of the report largely in line with the February QIR. Interestingly, members did sight concerns over dampening effects of global protectionism. UK data points (employment, inflation and retail sales) largely in line with the banks forecasts. Focus will turn to BoE member comments as we head towards the May meeting with hawkish talk likely to see GBP revisit the Jan’18 highs of 1.4344.

CAD: Bullish NAFTA noise and strong Canadian data at the back end of the week provided tailwind for the CAD with bets increasing that the slightly rosier outlook for the Canadian economy could point to another rate hike from the BoC. Friday’s inflation data printed at 2.2%, above the central banks price target, while hurdles in regards to the NAFTA looked to have eased with all three parties seemingly keen to reach an agreement. USD/CAD eying near term support targets of 1.28 with a firm break, suggesting a potential pullback to 1.26.

subject: BAML Weekly Flows: Equities see huge outflows, bonds see small inflows, precious metals see meaty inflows
content:
Equity Flows:

  • US: 2nd largest outflows ($24.9bn)
  • Japan: inflows for 16 straight weeks, first time since 2013 ($1.9bn)
  • Europe: modest outflows continue ($1.5bn)
  • EM: modest inflows ($2.0bn)
  • By style: 2nd largest outflows US large cap ($18.3bn) & US value ($7.2bn), outflows US growth ($3.4bn), US small cap ($2.2bn)
  • By sector: inflows into tech ($0.5bn), utilities ($0.4bn), consumer ($0.3bn), real estate ($0.2bn), materials ($0.001bn; outflows healthcare ($0.2bn), energy ($0.3bn), financials ($0.9bn)

 

Fixed Income Flows:

  • IG bond fund inflows 64 of past 65 weeks ($1.4bn)
  • HY bond outflows for 10 weeks, longest streak since 2007 ($1.6bn)
  • Small EM debt inflows ($0.5bn)
  • Small muni fund inflows ($0.4bn)
  • Govt/Tsy inflows for past 9 weeks, first time since Feb'16 ($1.5bn)
  • Record TIPS redemptions ($1.1bn)
  • Small bank loan fund inflows ($0.3bn)

Feds Bostic (Voter) says hes worried about responses to recent policy changes and also worries about uncertainty

Target (TGT) and Kroger (KR) reportedly discussing a merger
Fed's Bostic (voter, dovish) says further gradual rate hikes over the next couple of years are appropriate if economy develops as he expects
content:
• Says Fed needs to move rates towards 'neutral'
  • Fed is at or near inflation and unemployment goals
  • Bostic says that it might be prudent to raise rates less aggressively to gauge the impact of balance sheet reduction
  • Sees upside risks to labour costs , labour markets not yet overheated
  • Calm inflation will persist but risks are to the upside, sees potential for inflation to run somewhat above target
  • Worried about uncertainty and response to recent policy changes

  • Until a change in business investment is seen it is it is hard to see a fundamental change in growth trajectory

Scotiabank FX Daily - Trade Tensions Pummel Stocks, Supporting JPY
content:
• USD mostly lower as US rolls out trade tariffs. Durable goods due.
  • CAD steady but looking for support from domestic data releases.
  • EUR little changed in quiet trade; trend momentum is weak.
  • GBP consolidating early week gains. Near-term prospects improve on Brexit.
  • JPY cracks 105 as weakness in Asian stocks drives safe haven demand.
  • AUD outperforming on the day despite China trade concerns, equity volatility.
  • MXN steady on the session, focus on Jan IGAF economic activity data.

subject: Islamic State group claims hostage-taking in supermarkets in Toulouse South of France, according to prosecutors
DAILY US OPENING NEWS: Global equities hit by trade war concerns after China reportedly plans tariffs on USD 3bln of US imports
content:
• Global equities hit by trade war concerns after China reportedly plans tariffs on USD 3bln of US imports
  • FTQ into JPY has knocked USD/JPY back below 105.00 with USD softer across the board
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US durables, Canadian CPI and retail sales, EU council meeting and a slew of speakers

TRADE TARIFFS

China reportedly plans tariffs on USD 3bln of US imports, in which it plans 15% tariffs on US steel pipes, wine and fruits, while it also plans tariffs of 25% on US pork and pork products. Furthermore, there were also comments from Mofcom that China doesn't want a trade war but is not afraid of one, while the ministry added it hopes US will be prudent in its decisions and pulls back from the 'brink'. (Newswires)

Russia's Ministry of Trade and Industry said they are preparing restrictions on US imports as a response to US aluminium and steel tariffs.

EU’s Tusk states that EU leaders have called for a permanent exemption from US tariffs. (Newswires)

US has launched a WTO complaint over China’s “discriminatory technology licensing requirements”. (Newswires)

Source reports indicate that China intervened overnight to support its stock market after tariff announcements triggered losses. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian stocks saw hefty losses on trade war fears after the US announced USD 50bln of tariffs on China and with the latter planning tariffs of USD 3bln in retaliation, while it was also reported that National Security Advisor McMasters was replaced by policy hawk John Bolton. The intensified trade tensions triggered a bloodbath across stock markets with ASX 200 (-2.0%) led lower by miners as Chinese metals prices slumped on steel demand and tariff concerns, while Nikkei 225 (-4.5%) was the worst performer and briefly fell over 1000 points as selling pressure was magnified by a firmer JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-3.4%) conformed to the sell-off as Chinese stocks felt the pinch from the US trade offensive, while the PBoC refrained from open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 320bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded higher to track the gains in T-notes amid a safe-haven bid and with the BoJ present in the market under its massive bond buying program. This helped 10yr JGB prices back above 151.00 and saw the 10yr yield slip to below 0.025% which was its lowest since November.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 320bln vs. last week's CNY 240bln net injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3272 (Prev. 6.3167)

Japanese National CPI (Feb) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.4%). (Newswires)

Japanese National CPI Ex-Fresh Food (Feb) Y/Y 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 0.9%)

Japanese National CPI Ex-Food & Energy (Feb) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.4%)

CENTRAL BANKS

Russian Federation Bank of Russia key rate decision (Mar) 7.25% vs. Exp. 7.25% (Prev. 7.50%)

EU/UK/US

US House voted 256-167 and Senate voted 65-32 to pass the spending bill to fund government through to September 30th and avert a government shutdown, which gets sent to President Trump to sign into law. (Newswires)

US National Security Adviser McMaster is to resign and will be replaced by John Bolton. (Newswires)

President of the European Council Donald Tusk says EU leaders have formally adopted Brexit trade negotiating guidelines which include a transition offer. (Sky News) Note: this was widely-expected given the draft agreement announced earlier in the week.

Northern League’s leader Salvini says he will not break up the centre-right coalition. (La Repubblica) Note: Italy's Parliament is to hold a vote today aimed at electing speakers to both the Upper and Lower Houses that could push negotiations between rival parties to form a coalition government. The Five Star Movement (M5S), the Lega and Forza Italia have discussed appointing a speaker of their choice to one of the Houses, although disagreements already erupted.

EU leaders agreed to recall the bloc's ambassador to Russia over Salisbury attack, according to diplomatic sources. (Newswires) In related news, EU's Tusk stated that leaders agree with UK that Russia was highly likely to be responsible for the Salisbury attack, while there were also earlier reports that EU leaders discussed expulsion of Russian diplomats as a possible response. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are suffering heavy losses across the board with the Eurostoxx (-1.4%) hitting its lowest point since August 2017, continuing to remain hampered by the risk-off sentiment seen in US and Asia, after US announced USD 50bln tariffs on China triggering a retaliation of USD 3.1bln on US imports. Taking a closer look at sectors, materials (-1.8%) and industrials ( -1.6%) are lagging behind due to their vast exposure to the Chinese market and are immediately followed by IT (-1.9%), financials (-1.6%) and consumer discretionary (-1.3%). On the flip side, Next (+7.5%) is leading the FTSE100 after maintaining its profit guidance this morning and against the recent backdrop of the retail sector whilst GSK (+3.6%) is the outperformer in the index after it officially announced its withdrawal for its takeover of Pfizer’s health unit, following its rival Reckitt Benckiser who ended talks over the acquisition of the unit yesterday. Elsewhere, Indivior sank more than 20% at the open after the US court turned against the co. and is said to favour its competitor Alvogen. In the DAX, Deutsche Bank is down 12.7% for the week, extending losses over the widening LIBOR – OIS spread which is believed to provide a headwind for the bank.

FX

FX markets continue to be swayed by the prospect of ongoing ‘trade wars’ which have adopted more of a bilateral dynamic over the past 24 hours with exemptions for Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Mexico, South Korea and EU. In terms of the follow through for FX markets, the DXY is softer and back below 90.00 but largely a by-product of the safe-haven bid into JPY which knocked USD/JPY (temporarily) below 105.00 after the pair breached the YTD low at 105.23 during yesterday’s trade. From a technical perspective, some analysts are pointing towards 103.64 as a key level which marks the 76.4% Fib from the 99.00-118.66 recovery seen in 2016; a view held by IFR. Elsewhere, the USD softness has provided a modest lift to EUR/USD holding onto 1.2300, however GBP/USD gave up the 1.4100 handle. For EUR/USD, barring any major macro developments and amid a light data docket for the EZ, 2.3bln in expiries between 1.2250 and 1.2300 could act as a guiding force for prices. Back to GBP and amid the fallout of yesterday’s BoE release, focus for the UK will likely be on developments in Brussels at the EU council meeting (albeit seen as somewhat of a rubber stamp process). N.b. BoE Vlieghe to speak at 1230GMT. Elsewhere, AUD has also benefited from the softer USD despite the risk environment, albeit the pair may struggle to make any meaningful progress above 0.7730-40. Interestingly, despite concerns over potential faltering demand from China (Australia’s major trading partner), some suggest AUD could benefit if China opts to use Australian goods as a substitute for US ones. Moving forward, CAD will likely come into focus later today amid domestic CPI and retail sales releases. Traders will be looking to see if today’s releases conform to the recent slew of soft data whilst NAFTA concerns linger in the background. If this materialises, USD/CAD could make a firmer reclaiming of the 1.3000 level to the upside but would still have some way to go to hit the 2018 high around 1.3125.

FIXED INCOME

EGB’s have pulled off better levels despite the selloff observed in equity markets, however they do remain at elevated levels amid the trade war concerns. Bund’s trading in a relatively tight 20 tick range, earlier high just shy off the 159 level, further escalation of trade wars could see a breaching of this level. Elsewhere, peripheral markets are slightly wider vs core EGB’s with BTPs notably losing ground, down 30 ticks last. Italy’s parliament reconvenes today in order to find a solution to the current stalemate.

Bono’s set to come into focus later today as S&P reviews Spanish debt, many are indicating that this may be upgraded to A- from BBB+, which could provide tailwinds from being eligible for purchases by sovereign funds and central banks. Quite morning in the Gilt markets with EU confirming the UK’s transition period deal, as expected after the breakthrough earlier in the week. As such, Gilts are relatively flat to hover above 122, as a reminder, month-end extensions is seen at +0.22y for the GBP aggregate.

COMMODITIES

Taking a look at the commodities complex, WTI (+0.1%) and Brent Crude (+0.3%) are underpinned by the latest comment from Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih stating that there is still time to go before OPEC+ supply cut oil inventories to "normal levels" adding that OPEC/Non-OPEC will still require coordination in 2019. Additionally, the latest White House replacement of National Security Adviser HR McMaster with hardliner John Bolton, ahead of a key decision on May 12th regarding whether to maintain the Iran nuclear deal, raises the prospect of sanctions against Iran’s oil sales. Something to be aware of, with driving season edging closer, refineries are stocking up on crude oil to meet the seasonal demand for the summer driving season commencing in a few weeks. Moving onto metals, Gold (+1.0%) prices hit highs last seen in early February, boosted as investors flock into the traditional safe haven following the eruption of a trade war between US and China. Furthermore, a softer dollar this week has been supporting the yellow metal. Base metals on the other hand have fallen amid escalating trade concerns. Chinese steel futures fell more than 6%, hitting their lowest level in more than eight months while Dalian iron ore also shed over 6% hitting lows last seen in June 2017.

Lukoil VP says if US oil output continues to increase OPEC and Russia could extend oil cuts into 2019. (Newswires)

subject: EU MID-SESSION: Escalating trade war fears are looming in the market
content:
European equities are suffering heavy losses across the board with the Eurostoxx (-1.7%) hitting its lowest point since August 2017, continuing to remain hampered by the risk-off sentiment seen in US and Asia, after US announced USD 50bln tariffs on China triggering a retaliation of USD 3.1bln on US imports. Taking a closer look at sectors, materials (-2.3%) and industrials ( -2.0%) are lagging behind due to their vast exposure to the Chinese market and are immediately followed by IT (-2.0%), financials (-1.7%) and consumer discretionary (-1.7%). On the flip side, Next (+5.0%) is leading the FTSE100 after maintaining its profit guidance this morning and against the recent backdrop of the retail sector whilst GSK (+2.8%) is the outperformer in the index after it officially announced its withdrawal for its takeover of Pfizer’s health unit, following its rival Reckitt Benckiser who ended talks over the acquisition of the unit yesterday. In terms of the follow through for FX markets, the DXY is softer and back below 90.00 but largely a by-product of the safe-haven bid into JPY which knocked USD/JPY (temporarily) below 105.00 after the pair breached the YTD low at 105.23 during yesterday’s trade. From a technical perspective, some analysts are pointing towards 103.64 as a key level which marks the 76.4% Fib from the 99.00-118.66 recovery seen in 2016; a view held by IFR. Elsewhere, the USD softness has provided a modest lift to EUR/USD holding onto 1.2300, however GBP/USD gave up the 1.4100 handle. Back to GBP and amid the fallout of yesterday’s BoE release, focus for the UK will likely be on developments in Brussels at the EU council meeting (albeit seen as somewhat of a rubber stamp process). N.b. BoE Vleighe to speak at 1230GMT. Elsewhere, AUD has also benefited from the softer USD despite the risk environment, albeit the pair may struggle to make any meaningful progress above 0.7730-40. Interestingly, despite concerns over potential faltering demand from China (Australia’s major trading partner), some suggest AUD could benefit if China opts to use Australian goods as a substitute for US ones. Traders will be looking to see if today’s releases conforms to the recent slew of soft data whilst NAFTA concerns linger in the background. If this materialises, USD/CAD could make a firmer reclaiming of the 1.3000 level to the upside but would still have some way to go to hit the 2018 high around 1.3125.

EGB’s have pulled off better levels despite the selloff observed in equity markets, however they do remain at elevated levels amid the trade war concerns. Bund’s trading in a relatively tight 20 tick range, earlier high just shy off the 159 level, further escalation of trade wars could see a breaching of this level. Elsewhere, peripheral markets are slightly wider vs core EGB’s with BTPs notably losing ground, down 30 ticks last. Italy’s parliament reconvenes today in order to find a solutions to the current stalemate.

Bono’s set to come into focus later today as S&P reviews Spanish debt, many are indicating that this may be upgraded to A- from BBB+, which could provide tailwinds from being eligible for purchases by sovereign funds and central banks. Quite morning in the Gilt markets with EU confirming the UK’s transition period deal, as expected after the breakthrough earlier in the week. As such, Gilts are relatively flat to hover above 122, as a reminder, month-end extensions is seen at +0.22y for the GBP aggregate.

Taking a look at the commodities complex, WTI (+0.1%) and Brent Crude (+0.3%) are underpinned by the latest comment from Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih stating that there is still time to go before OPEC+ supply cut oil inventories to "normal levels" adding that OPEC/Non-OPEC will still require coordination in 2019. Additionally, the latest White House replacement of National Security Adviser HR McMaster with hardliner John Bolton, ahead of a key decision on May 12th regarding whether to maintain the Iran nuclear deal, raises the prospect of sanctions against Iran’s oil sales. Something to be aware of, with driving season edging closer, refineries are stocking up on crude oil to meet the seasonal demand for the summer driving season commencing in a few weeks. Moving onto metals, Gold (+1.0%) prices hit highs last seen in early February, boosted as investors flock into the traditional safe haven following the eruption of a trade war between US and China. Furthermore, a softer dollar this week has been supporting the yellow metal. Base metals on the other hand have fallen amid escalating trade concerns. Chinese steel futures fell more than 6%, hitting their lowest level in more than eight months while Dalian iron ore also shed over 6% hitting lows last seen in June 2017.

subject: EU MID-SESSION: Escalating trade war fears are looming in the market
content:
European equities are suffering heavy losses across the board with the Eurostoxx (-1.7%) hitting its lowest point since August 2017, continuing to remain hampered by the risk-off sentiment seen in US and Asia, after US announced USD 50bln tariffs on China triggering a retaliation of USD 3.1bln on US imports. Taking a closer look at sectors, materials (-2.3%) and industrials ( -2.0%) are lagging behind due to their vast exposure to the Chinese market and are immediately followed by IT (-2.0%), financials (-1.7%) and consumer discretionary (-1.7%). On the flip side, Next (+5.0%) is leading the FTSE100 after maintaining its profit guidance this morning and against the recent backdrop of the retail sector whilst GSK (+2.8%) is the outperformer in the index after it officially announced its withdrawal for its takeover of Pfizer’s health unit, following its rival Reckitt Benckiser who ended talks over the acquisition of the unit yesterday. Elsewhere, Indivior sank more than 20% at the open after the US court turned against the co. and is said to favour its competitor Alvogen. In the DAX, Deutsche Bank is down 12.7% for the week, extending losses over the widening LIBOR – OIS spread which is believed to provide a headwind for the bank.

FX markets continue to be swayed by the prospect of ongoing ‘trade wars’ which have adopted more of a bilateral dynamic over the past 24 hours with exemptions for Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Mexico, South Korea and EU. In terms of the follow through for FX markets, the DXY is softer and back below 90.00 but largely a by-product of the safe-haven bid into JPY which knocked USD/JPY (temporarily) below 105.00 after the pair breached the YTD low at 105.23 during yesterday’s trade. From a technical perspective, some analysts are pointing towards 103.64 as a key level which marks the 76.4% Fib from the 99.00-118.66 recovery seen in 2016; a view held by IFR. Elsewhere, the USD softness has provided a modest lift to EUR/USD holding onto 1.2300, however GBP/USD gave up the 1.4100 handle. For EUR/USD, barring any major macro developments and amid a light data docket for the EZ, 2.3bln in expiries between 1.2250 and 1.2300 could act as a guiding force for prices. Back to GBP and amid the fallout of yesterday’s BoE release, focus for the UK will likely be on developments in Brussels at the EU council meeting (albeit seen as somewhat of a rubber stamp process). N.b. BoE Vleighe to speak at 1230GMT. Elsewhere, AUD has also benefited from the softer USD despite the risk environment, albeit the pair may struggle to make any meaningful progress above 0.7730-40. Interestingly, despite concerns over potential faltering demand from China (Australia’s major trading partner), some suggest AUD could benefit if China opts to use Australian goods as a substitute for US ones. Moving forward, CAD will likely come into focus later today amid domestic CPI and retail sales releases. Traders will be looking to see if today’s releases conforms to the recent slew of soft data whilst NAFTA concerns linger in the background. If this materialises, USD/CAD could make a firmer reclaiming of the 1.3000 level to the upside but would still have some way to go to hit the 2018 high around 1.3125.

EGB’s have pulled off better levels despite the selloff observed in equity markets, however they do remain at elevated levels amid the trade war concerns. Bund’s trading in a relatively tight 20 tick range, earlier high just shy off the 159 level, further escalation of trade wars could see a breaching of this level. Elsewhere, peripheral markets are slightly wider vs core EGB’s with BTPs notably losing ground, down 30 ticks last. Italy’s parliament reconvenes today in order to find a solutions to the current stalemate.

Bono’s set to come into focus later today as S&P reviews Spanish debt, many are indicating that this may be upgraded to A- from BBB+, which could provide tailwinds from being eligible for purchases by sovereign funds and central banks. Quite morning in the Gilt markets with EU confirming the UK’s transition period deal, as expected after the breakthrough earlier in the week. As such, Gilts are relatively flat to hover above 122, as a reminder, month-end extensions is seen at +0.22y for the GBP aggregate.

Taking a look at the commodities complex, WTI (+0.1%) and Brent Crude (+0.3%) are underpinned by the latest comment from Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih stating that there is still time to go before OPEC+ supply cut oil inventories to "normal levels" adding that OPEC/Non-OPEC will still require coordination in 2019. Additionally, the latest White House replacement of National Security Adviser HR McMaster with hardliner John Bolton, ahead of a key decision on May 12th regarding whether to maintain the Iran nuclear deal, raises the prospect of sanctions against Iran’s oil sales. Something to be aware of, with driving season edging closer, refineries are stocking up on crude oil to meet the seasonal demand for the summer driving season commencing in a few weeks. Moving onto metals, Gold (+1.0%) prices hit highs last seen in early February, boosted as investors flock into the traditional safe haven following the eruption of a trade war between US and China. Furthermore, a softer dollar this week has been supporting the yellow metal. Base metals on the other hand have fallen amid escalating trade concerns. Chinese steel futures fell more than 6%, hitting their lowest level in more than eight months while Dalian iron ore also shed over 6% hitting lows last seen in June 2017.

subject: Source reports indicate that China intervened overnight to support its stock market after tariff announcements triggered losses
content: • As a reminder, US President Trump announced USD 50bln tariffs against China over IP theft under section '301' meaning that the WTO can be circumvented, in retaliation China reportedly plans tariffs on USD 3bln of US imports, which led to sell in Asian equities with the Shanghai Composite seeing losses of 3.4%.

subject: US has launched a WTO complaint over China’s “discriminatory technology licensing requirements”
City of London Police tweet: The cordons put up around St Mary Axe due to a suspicious package have been lifted and the area is now clear
Lukoil VP says if US oil output continues to increase OPEC and Russia could extend oil cuts into 2019
President of the European Council Donald Tusk says EU leaders have formally adopted Brexit trade negotiating guidelines which include a transition offer, via Sky News
analysis_details: - Note, this was widely-expected given the draft agreement announced earlier in the week.

subject: EU Tusk Spokesperson: Trade discussion finished and EUCO conclusions adopted. Brexit EUCO started and guidelines adopted. Both documents will be published asap.
City of London Police: We've put cordons around St Mary Axe (in the City of London/financial district) due to a report of a suspicious package (a box) in Bury St received at 8.56am
Russia's Ministry of Trade and Industry said they are preparing restrictions on US imports as a response to US aluminium and steel tariffs
analysis_details:
• This comes following China reportedly planning tariffs on USD 3bln of US imports, in which it plans 15% tariffs on US steel pipes, wine and fruits, while it also plans tariffs of 25% on US pork and pork products. Furthermore, there were also comments from Mofcom that China doesn't want a trade war but is not afraid of one, while the ministry added it hopes US will be prudent in its decisions and pulls back from the 'brink'.
  • US President Trump announced USD 50bln tariffs against China over IP theft under section '301' meaning that the WTO can be circumvented. According to the reports, the US could seek to limit Chinese acquisitions in the US and will also challenge licensing practices at WTO. Furthermore, the US is to publish a list of products that could be targeted for tariffs within 15 days of signing the presidential memorandum, while a 30-day consultation period was also announced, and President Trump later commented that tariffs could amount up to USD 60bln.

analysis_details: Italy's Parliament is to hold a vote today aimed at electing speakers to both the Upper and Lower Houses that could push negotiations between rival parties to form a coalition government. The Five Star Movement (M5S) , the Lega and  Forza Italia have discussed appointing a speaker of their choice to one of the Houses, although disagreements already erupted.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Deutsche Wohnen (DWNI GY) – FY 2017 adj. EBITDA EUR 600.8mln vs. Prev. EUR 575.1mln and net EUR 1.76bln vs. Prev. EUR 1.62bln. (Newswires)

GSK (GSK LN) – Co. confirms it has withdrawn from the process relating to Pfizer’s consumer healthcare business. Separately Shingrix drug for the prevention of shingles and post-herpetic neuralgia (PHN) in age 50+ has been approved in EU and Japan. (Newswires)

Next (NXT LN) – FY 2017 revenue GBP 4.06bln vs. Exp. GBP 4.13bln, profit-before tax GBP 726.1mln vs. Prev. GBP 790.2mln, EPS -5.6% to GBP 4.167. Pricing environment is to be more benign in 2018/19. (Newswires)

Smiths Group (SMIN LN) – Operating profit of GBP 247mln was down 2% on an underlying basis. H1 revenue down 4% to GBP 1.549bln. Interim dividend GBP 0.138/shr. 2018 FY outlook reaffirmed. John Crane delivered good performance, returning to growth with revenue +3% on an underlying 2 basis. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM)/Vivendi (VIV FP) – Elliott advisors say Vivendi’s move over Telecom Italia is “cynical and self-serving” but not surprising. Elliott adds that Vivendi’s move is another example of disregard toward minority shareholder rights at Telecom Italia. (Newswires)

Sanofi (SAN FP) - Torrent Pharma is said to shelve bid for the Co. generic drug unit. (Newswires) As a reminder, Torrent Pharma had previously mulled a EUR 2bln offer. (Newswires)

Shell (RDSA LN) – Shell EP Middle East agreed to sell entire share capital of Shell Iraq B.V for USD 406mln to a subsidiary of Itochu Corporation (8001 JP). (Newswires)

Aviva (AV/ LN) – Co. has given into investor pressure and has scrapped its decision to cancel GBP 450mln of high-yielding preference shares. (FT)  

Indivior (INDV LN) – US court has found that Alvogen does not infringe asserted claims of certain US patents. (Newswires)

CARNIVAL (CCL LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

MITIE Group (MTO LN) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

SANOFI (SAN FP) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT LIBERUM

PRUDENTIAL (PRU LN) UPGRADED TO REDUCE FROM SELL AT ALPHAVALUE

WENDEL INVESTISSEMENT (MF FP) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT SOCGEN

VALMET (VALMT FH) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT DNB MARKETS

SHELL (RDSA LN) UPGRADED TO BUY AT SOCGEN

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from Unilever, Deutsche Bank, E.ON and RWE
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

23rd March 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks saw hefty losses on trade war fears after the US announced USD 50bln of tariffs on China and with the latter planning tariffs of USD 3bln in retaliation, while it was also reported that National Security Advisor McMasters was replaced by policy hawk John Bolton. The intensified trade tensions triggered a bloodbath across stock markets with ASX 200 (-2.0%) led lower by miners as Chinese metals prices slumped on steel demand and tariff concerns, while Nikkei 225 (-4.6%) was the worst performer and briefly fell over 1000 points as selling pressure was magnified by a firmer JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-3.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-3.4%) conformed to the sell-off as Chinese stocks felt the pinch from the US trade offensive, while the PBoC refrained from open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 320bln.

FTSE

Unilever (ULVR LN) – Shareholder Columbia Threadneedle Investments criticised the co. saying it failed to consult British investors over the implications of last week’s decision to establish a single legal base in Rotterdam. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – the EU have approved hyperkalaemia therapy Lokelman. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co. has priced the IPO of DWS (its asset management arm) at EUR 32.50 a share. The bank will sell 22.5% of the co. which has assets over EUR 700bln under management, raising EUR 1.4bln. (Newswires)

E.ON (EOAN GY)/ RWE (RWE GY) – Cos. are not planning to merge after shaking up the German market with an asset swap, according to CEOs of both companies. (Newswires)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Lufthansa Cargo expects 2018 profits not to be as high as last year’s EUR 242mln, with average yields set to be lower than 2017. (Newswires)

Adidas (ADS GY) – Nike Inc (NKE) reports Q3 EPS 0.68 USD vs. Exp. USD 0.53, revenue USD 9.0bln vs. Exp. USD 8.85bln

BROKER MOVES

EON (EOAN GY) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Ipsen (IPN FP) – The CHMP has issued a positive opinion for cabometyx for aRCC. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN-EUROPE

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Co. acknowledges the resignation of deputy chairman and chairman, alongside five other directors, and representatives from Vivendi (VIV FP) in the board, triggering a full board reshuffle. (Newswires)

Enel (ENEL IM) – 2017 net ordinary profit +14.4% to EUR 3.71bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.60bln. Co. proposes dividend over 2017 results of EUR 0.237/shr. Co. confirms financial targets for 2018. (Newswires)

SMI

Novartis (NOVN SW) – Co. plans to file its BAF312 drug for the treatment of multiple sclerosis and obtain US approval as it seeks to update its neurological medicines’ portfolio on which patents are about to expire. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

* EQUITIES: SPX -2.53% at 2643, NDX -2.50% at 6682 and DJI -2.95% at 23955

* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): -1.99%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -0.89%, ENERGY (XLE): -2.09%, FINANCIALS (XLF): -3.32%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): -2.90%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): -3.30%, MATERIALS (XLB): -2.94%, TECH (XLK): -2.73%, TELECOMS (XTL): -1.33%, UTLITIES (XLU): +0.45%.

* US equity futures are lower for a second day amid concerns about trade wars, and following on from yesterday’s FOMC rate decision. The 100dma was a focus for Emini S&P traders, with the index breaching the level going into the last leg of trade. US President Trump announced $50bln of annual tariffs on China over IP theft, as expected, which gave a slight lift to US equities. However, as China threatened to hit back at the US with retaliations, basic materials took a hit with steel and aluminium names (X, NUE, STLD) all took a leg lower. Utilities were positive for much of the session (the only green sector), as some defensive names caught a bid following trade war newsflow. After market, earnings from Nike (NKE), Micron (MU) and Cintas (CTAS) are due.

subject: BofAML Flow Show
content:
Flows: risk-off, hint peak yields & credit cracking but no positioning for Occupy Silicon Valley or Trade War. Meaty $1.5bn inflows to gold, $1.8bn into bonds, big $19.9bn equity redemptions (follows record inflow last week & huge $151.7bn YTD)

Positioning pain trade still lower stocks, higher CNY, lower bond yields on peaking PMI/EPS

Protagonists for new lows in SPX watch...5s30s <25bp, JPY <100, DAX <12,000, Bitcoin <6,000

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks saw hefty losses after the US announced USD 50bln of tariffs on China with the latter planning tariffs of USD 3bln in retaliation
content:
• Asian stocks saw hefty losses after the US announced USD 50bln of tariffs on China with the latter planning tariffs of USD 3bln in retaliation
  • In FX, price action remained dictated by the risk sentiment in which safe-haven JPY outperformed
  • Looking ahead, highlights include the Russian rate decision, US durables, Canadian CPI and retail sales, EU council meeting and a slew of speakers

TRADE TARIFFS

US President Trump announced USD 50bln tariffs against China over IP theft under section '301' meaning that the WTO can be circumvented. According to the reports, the US could seek to limit Chinese acquisitions in the US and will also challenge licensing practices at WTO. Furthermore, the US is to publish a list of products that could be targeted for tariffs within 15 days of signing the presidential memorandum, while a 30-day consultation period was also announced, and President Trump later commented that tariffs could amount up to USD 60bln. (Newswires)

US President Trump Administration issued tariff exemptions to Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada, Mexico, South Korea and EU with the tariffs suspended until May 2nd. (Newswires)

China reportedly plans tariffs on USD 3bln of US imports, in which it plans 15% tariffs on US steel pipes, wine and fruits, while it also plans tariffs of 25% on US pork and pork products. Furthermore, there were also comments from Mofcom that China doesn't want a trade war but is not afraid of one, while the ministry added it hopes US will be prudent in its decisions and pulls back from the 'brink'. (Newswires)
 

ASIA

Asian stocks saw hefty losses on trade war fears after the US announced USD 50bln of tariffs on China and with the latter planning tariffs of USD 3bln in retaliation, while it was also reported that National Security Advisor McMasters was replaced by policy hawk John Bolton. The intensified trade tensions triggered a bloodbath across stock markets with ASX 200 (-2.0%) led lower by miners as Chinese metals prices slumped on steel demand and tariff concerns, while Nikkei 225 (-4.6%) was the worst performer and briefly fell over 1000 points as selling pressure was magnified by a firmer JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-3.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-3.4%) conformed to the sell-off as Chinese stocks felt the pinch from the US trade offensive, while the PBoC refrained from open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 320bln. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded higher to track the gains in T-notes amid a safe-haven bid and with the BoJ present in the market under its massive bond buying program. This helped 10yr JGB prices back above 151.00 and saw the 10yr yield slip to below 0.025% which was its lowest since November.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 320bln vs. last week's CNY 240bln net injection. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3272 (Prev. 6.3167)

Japanese National CPI (Feb) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.4%). (Newswires)
Japanese National CPI Ex-Fresh Food (Feb) Y/Y 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.0% (Prev. 0.9%)
Japanese National CPI Ex-Food & Energy (Feb) Y/Y 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.4%)

UK/EU

EU leaders agreed to recall the bloc's ambassador to Russia over Salisbury attack, according to diplomatic sources. (Newswires) In related news, EU's Tusk stated that leaders agree with UK that Russia was highly likely to be responsible for the Salisbury attack, while there were also earlier reports that EU leaders discussed expulsion of Russian diplomats as a possible response. (Newswires)

ECB’s Draghi reportedly gave an optimistic outlook to EU leaders, but noted protectionism is the largest economic risk. (Newswires)

EU formally appointed Luis de Guindos as ECB Vice President as expected. (Newswires)

Catalan separatist candidate Turull failed to win presidency in Catalan parliamentary vote. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, price action remained dictated by the risk sentiment in which safe-haven JPY outperformed amid the trade tension turmoil, which saw USD/JPY slip below the 105.00 handle for the first time since late 2016. Elsewhere, DXY was subdued and languished below the 90.00 level as the greenback’s major counterparts nursed losses, with EUR/USD supported at 1.2300 and GBP/USD holding onto the 1.4100 handle, while commodity-linked currencies also found mild relief amid overnight gains in oil and gold.

Riksbank's Jansson said expects SEK to appreciate gradually and that SEK is not in a downtrend. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with oil underpinned following comments from Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih that OPEC/Non-OPEC will still require coordination in 2019. Gold also gained overnight on a safe-haven bid and amid a subdued greenback. Conversely, base metals underperformed as Dalian iron ore futures and   Rebar slumped over 5% in early trade triggered by concerns regarding steel demand and US tariffs.

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih said that two thirds of the glut is gone, but added there is still time to go before OPEC+ supply cut oil inventories to "normal levels". Furthermore, Al-Falih also commented that OPEC/Non-OPEC will still require coordination in 2019. (Newswires)


US

Volume in treasuries was heavier on Thursday than it was on Wednesday (when the Fed lifted rates). The curve flattened, with most of the action being seen in the belly, where yields on 10s breached 2.80%, the third time in March. However, at settlement, the 10 was above that level. The UST auctioned $11bln of 10-year TIPS, stopping-through the screens by 0.1bps, and cover above recent averages. T-notes settled 18 ticks higher at 120-16+.

US House voted 256-167 and Senate voted 65-32 to pass the spending bill to fund government through to September 30th and avert a government shutdown, which gets sent to President Trump to sign into law. (Newswires)

US National Security Adviser McMaster is to resign and will be replaced by John Bolton. (Newswires)

subject: Moody's raises Tencent (700 HK) credit rating to A1 from A2; Outlook Stable
Nikkei 225 closes down 4.5% at 20,617

MS: Short NZDCAD with a target of 0.8800, stop at 0.9500. They point to a constructive NAFTA outlook risks tilted to a more dovish RBNZ via the new PTA (in their view), with NZ data seen as un-compelling. Risks include dovish shift from BoC

ASIA-PAC MID SESSION UPDATE: Trade tensions spark bloodbath is Asia stocks
content:
Asia stocks trade with hefty losses on trade war fears after the US announced USD 50bln of tariffs on China and with the latter planning tariffs on USD 3bln of US imports in retaliation, while it was also reported that National Security Advisor McMasters was replaced by policy hawk John Bolton. The intensified trade tensions triggered a bloodbath across stock markets with ASX 200 (-2.1%) led lower by miners as Chinese metals prices slump on steel demand and tariff concerns, while Nikkei 225 (-3.7%) is the worst performer as selling pressure is magnified by a firmer JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-3.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.9%) conform to the sell-off as Chinese stocks feel the pinch from the US trade offensive and with the PBoC refraining from open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 320bln.

In FX markets, price action remained dictated by the risk sentiment with safe-haven JPY outperforming amid the trade tension turmoil, which saw USD/JPY slip below the 105.00 handle for the first time since late 2016. Elsewhere, USD remains subdued and languishes below the 90.00 level as its major counterparts nurse losses, after EUR/USD found support at 1.2300 and with GBP/USD attempting to gain a firmer footing on the 1.4100 handle. Commodity-linked currencies have also found mild relief overnight as gold gains on safe-haven flows and with oil underpinned following comments from Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih that OPEC/Non-OPEC will still require coordination in 2019.

Finally, 10yr JGBs traded higher to track the gains in T-notes amid a safe-haven bid and with the BoJ present in the market under its massive bond buying program. This helped 10yr JGB prices back above 151.00 and saw the 10yr yield slip to below 0.025% which was its lowest since November.

Asia equity markets open with heavy losses as region follows suit to global stock rout amid trade war concerns after the US announced USD 50bln of tariffs on China and with China threatening retaliation; ASX 200 (-1.6%), Nikkei 225 (-3.0%), KOSPI (-1.9%)
